title: Ex-MEP Elmar Brok appointed EU adviser on Ukraine
text:
Former German MEP Elmar Brock will take up an unpaid position as EU adviser on Ukraine | Mladen Antonov/AFP via Getty Images Ex-MEP Elmar Brok appointed EU adviser on Ukraine Controversial German Christian Democrat to offer counsel to Commission chief Juncker.

Elmar Brok is back — for the next couple of months, at least.

The German Christian Democrat, who spent nearly 40 years as an MEP, has been appointed a special adviser to outgoing European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker on relations with Ukraine, the EU executive said Wednesday.

Brok will take up the position, which is unpaid, immediately. Juncker is due to leave office on October 31, to be replaced by former German Defense Minister Ursula von der Leyen.

In his new position, Brok will advise Juncker on "strategy and priorities in relations with Ukraine in the aftermath of the country's presidential and parliamentary elections earlier this year," according to the Commission.

Brok was one of the European Parliament's most prominent members, having served as the chairman of its foreign affairs committee. He is also a controversial figure. He faced criticism for holding a position at German media giant Bertelsmann while also serving as an MEP and for running a system that charged visitors to the European Parliament, ostensibly to cover costs but which generated financial surpluses. Brok later repaid the excess funds.

Brok's new job will not go down well with everyone in Ukraine. In 2013, he was attacked by a member of the activist group Femen outside the European Parliament following reports — denied by Brok and EU institutions — that he had visited a brothel in Ukraine and made degrading comments about women.
description: Controversial German Christian Democrat to offer counsel to Commission chief Juncker.
